title: Boreas Pass
text:
Boreas Pass (elevation ) is a high <a href="mountain%20pass">mountain pass</a> in central <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>, in the <a href="Rocky%20Mountains">Rocky Mountains</a> of the <a href="western%20United%20States">western United States</a>. The pass is located on the <a href="continental%20divide">continental divide</a>, at the crest of the <a href="Front%20Range">Front Range</a> along the border between <a href="Park%20County%2C%20Colorado">Park</a> (south) and <a href="Summit%20County%2C%20Colorado">Summit</a> counties.
Description.
The pass crosses the range where it divides the headwaters of the <a href="Blue%20River%20%28Colorado%29">Blue River</a> (a tributary of the <a href="Colorado%20River%20%28U.S.%29">Colorado River</a>) to the north with <a href="South%20Park%20%28Park%20County%2C%20Colorado%29">South Park</a> and the headwaters of the <a href="South%20Platte%20River">South Platte River</a> to the south. It is traversed by <a href="United%20States%20Forest%20Service">Forest Service</a> Road 33, a gravel road that is closed in winter but passable by two-wheel drive automobiles in good weather. In winter, the road is used by cross-country skiers. The road over the pass goes north from the town of <a href="Como%2C%20Colorado">Como</a> in the northern South Park northeast of <a href="Fairplay%2C%20Colorado">Fairplay</a>, crossing the path northward to <a href="Breckenridge%2C%20Colorado">Breckenridge</a>. In good weather, it furnishes an alternative route to nearby <a href="Hoosier%20Pass%20%28Continental%20Divide%29">Hoosier Pass</a>, offering splendid views of <a href="aspen">aspen</a> trees and nearby <a href="Mount%20Silverheels">Mount Silverheels</a> and the <a href="Tenmile%20Range">Tenmile Range</a>. The round trip up to the top from Breckenridge is popular with bicyclists.
The pass was formerly known as Breckenridge Pass in the 1860s, when it served as an early route for thousands of prospectors during the <a href="Colorado%20Gold%20Rush">Colorado Gold Rush</a> who crossed from South Park to look for <a href="gold">gold</a> in the valley of the Blue around Breckenridge. In 1866, it was widened to a wagon road that accommodated <a href="stagecoach">stagecoach</a>es. In 1882, under the direction of <a href="Sidney%20Dillon">Sidney Dillon</a> of the <a href="Union%20Pacific%20Railroad">Union Pacific Railroad</a>, the <a href="Denver%2C%20South%20Park%20and%20Pacific%20Railroad">Denver, South Park and Pacific Railroad</a> (by then controlled by the Union Pacific) begun laying <a href="narrow%20gauge%20railway">narrow gauge</a> tracks up the pass, which Dillon renamed in honor of <a href="Anemoi%23Boreas">Boreas</a>, the <a href="Ancient%20Greece">Ancient Greek</a> god of the North Wind. The line was a spur to Breckenridge (eventually extended to <a href="Leadville%2C%20Colorado">Leadville</a>) off the company's main line from <a href="Denver%2C%20Colorado">Denver</a> through South Park. A roundhouse, still in existence, was constructed at <a href="Como%2C%20Colorado">Como</a> at the junction of the lines. The rail line over the pass was a major engineering feat, primarily because of the winter snows at high altitude. When completed, it had dozens of <a href="snow%20shed">snow shed</a>s along its route, which approached a 4% grade in many places. A town of <a href="Boreas%2C%20Colorado">Boreas</a>, now a <a href="ghost%20town">ghost town</a>, was constructed at the summit, primarily to house workers to clear the line in winter. The line was abandoned in 1937 by the <a href="Colorado%20%26amp%3B%20Southern">Colorado & Southern</a>, along with most of the company's narrow gauge <a href="Right-of-way%20%28railroad%29">right-of-way</a>. After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Corps%20of%20Engineers">Army Corps of Engineers</a> reconstructed the route for automobile traffic. On the north side of the pass, Forest Service Road 593 leads to the 1880s ghost town site of <a href="Dyersville%2C%20Colorado">Dyersville</a>, as well as many abandoned <a href="mining">mining</a> sites.
The Boreas Pass Ditch was completed in 1910 to <a href="Water%20diversion">divert</a> water over the pass from the headwaters of Indiana Creek, a tributary of the <a href="Blue%20River%20%28Colorado%29">Blue River</a> into North <a href="Tarryall%20Creek">Tarryall Creek</a>, a tributary of the <a href="South%20Platte%20River">South Platte River</a>. The 0.8 mile (1.3 km) ditch has a capacity of 16 cubic feet per second (0.45m3/s), and in an average year, it transports about 140 acre-feet (170,000m3) of water. The ditch was originally built to <a href="irrigation">irrigate</a> land in <a href="South%20Park%20%28Park%20County%2C%20Colorado%29">South Park</a>, but it currently serves the city of <a href="Englewood%2C%20Colorado">Englewood</a>, which rehabilitated the ditch In 1990.
The <a href="Boreas%20Railroad%20Station%20Site">Boreas Railroad Station Site</a> is listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>.
